"**Hey Jude** " is a song by the English [rock](/wiki/Rock_music "Rock music")
band [the Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles"), written by [Paul
McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney") and credited to
[Lennon–McCartney](/wiki/Lennon%E2%80%93McCartney "Lennon–McCartney"). The
[ballad](/wiki/Ballad "Ballad") evolved from "Hey Jules", a song McCartney
wrote to comfort [John Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon")'s son,
[Julian](/wiki/Julian_Lennon "Julian Lennon"), during his parents' divorce.
"Hey Jude" begins with a verse-bridge structure incorporating McCartney's
vocal performance and piano accompaniment; further instrumentation is added as
the song progresses. After the fourth verse, the song shifts to a fade-out
[coda](/wiki/Coda_\(music\) "Coda \(music\)") that lasts for more than four
minutes.

"Hey Jude" was released in August 1968 as the first single from the Beatles'
record label [Apple Records](/wiki/Apple_Records "Apple Records"). More than
seven minutes in length, it was at the time the longest single ever to top the
British charts.[1] It also spent nine weeks at number one in the United
States, the longest for any Beatles single. "Hey Jude" tied the "all-time"
record, at the time, for the longest run at the top of the US charts. The
single has sold approximately eight million copies and is frequently included
on professional critics' lists of the greatest songs of all time. In 2013,
_[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard \(magazine\)")_ named it
the 10th biggest song of all time.[2]

## Inspiration and
writing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Inspiration and writing")]

In May 1968,[3] [John Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon") and his wife
[Cynthia Lennon](/wiki/Cynthia_Lennon "Cynthia Lennon") separated after John's
affair with [Yoko Ono](/wiki/Yoko_Ono "Yoko Ono").[4] The following month,
[Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney") drove out to visit
Cynthia and John's son, [Julian](/wiki/Julian_Lennon "Julian Lennon"),[5] at
[Kenwood](/wiki/Kenwood,_St._George%27s_Hill "Kenwood, St. George's Hill"),
the family's home in [Weybridge](/wiki/Weybridge "Weybridge").[6] Cynthia had
been part of [the Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles")' social circle
since before the band's rise to fame in 1963;[7] McCartney later said he found
it "a bit much for them suddenly to be _[personae non
gratae](/wiki/Persona_non_grata "Persona non grata")_ and out of my life."[8]
Cynthia Lennon recalled of McCartney's surprise visit: "I was touched by his
obvious concern for our welfare ... On the journey down he composed 'Hey Jude'
in the car. I will never forget Paul's gesture of care and concern in coming
to see us."[9]

I started with the idea "Hey Jules," which was Julian, don't make it bad, take
a sad song and make it better. Hey, try and deal with this terrible thing. I
knew it was not going to be easy for him. I always feel sorry for kids in
divorces...[8]

– [Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney"), 1997

The song's original title was "Hey Jules", and it was intended to comfort
Julian Lennon from the stress of his parents' separation.[4] McCartney later
said, "I knew it was not going to be easy for him", and that he changed the
name to "Jude" "because I thought that sounded a bit better".[8]

According to music journalist Chris Hunt, in the weeks after writing the song,
McCartney "test[ed] his latest composition on anyone too polite to refuse. And
that meant _everyone_."[10] On 30 June, after recording the [Black Dyke Mills
Band](/wiki/Black_Dyke_Mills_Band "Black Dyke Mills Band")'s rendition of his
instrumental "Thingumybob", in [Yorkshire](/wiki/Yorkshire "Yorkshire"),
McCartney stopped at a village in [Bedfordshire](/wiki/Bedfordshire
"Bedfordshire") and performed "Hey Jude" at a local pub.[11] He also regaled
members of [the Bonzo Dog Band](/wiki/The_Bonzo_Dog_Band "The Bonzo Dog Band")
with the song while producing their single "[I'm the Urban
Spaceman](/wiki/I%27m_the_Urban_Spaceman "I'm the Urban Spaceman")", in
London, and interrupted a recording session by [the Barron
Knights](/wiki/The_Barron_Knights "The Barron Knights") to do the same.[10]
Ron Griffith of the group the Iveys – soon to be known as
[Badfinger](/wiki/Badfinger "Badfinger") and, like the Black Dyke Mills Band,
an early signing to the Beatles' new record label [Apple
Records](/wiki/Apple_Records "Apple Records") – later recalled that on their
first day in the studio, McCartney "gave us a full concert rendition of 'Hey
Jude'".[12][nb 1]

When introducing the composition to Lennon, McCartney assured him that he
would "fix" the line "the movement you need is on your shoulder", reasoning
that "it's a stupid expression; it sounds like a parrot." Lennon replied: "You
won't, you know. That's the best line in the song."[13] McCartney retained the
phrase;[4] he later said of his subsequent live performances of the song:
"that's the line when I think of John, and sometimes I get a little emotional
during that moment."[13]

If you think about it ... Yoko's just come into the picture. He's saying.
"Hey, Jude – Hey, John." I know I'm sounding like one of those fans who reads
things into it, but you can _hear_ it as a song to me ... Subconsciously, he
was saying, Go ahead, leave me. On a conscious level, he didn't want me to go
ahead.[14]

– [John Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon"), 1980

Although McCartney originally wrote "Hey Jude" for Julian, John Lennon thought
it had actually been written for him. In a 1980 interview, Lennon stated that
he "always heard it as a song to me" and contended that, on one level,
McCartney was giving his blessing to Lennon and Ono's relationship, while, on
another, he was disappointed to be usurped as Lennon's friend and songwriting
partner.[14]

Other people believed McCartney wrote the song about them, including Judith
Simons, a journalist with the _[Daily Express](/wiki/Daily_Express "Daily
Express")_.[15] Still others, including Lennon, have speculated that in the
lyrics to "Hey Jude", McCartney's failing long-term relationship with [Jane
Asher](/wiki/Jane_Asher "Jane Asher") provided an unconscious "message to
himself".[16] McCartney and Asher had announced their engagement on 25
December 1967,[17] yet he began an affair with [Linda
Eastman](/wiki/Linda_McCartney "Linda McCartney") in June 1968;[18] that same
month, [Francie Schwartz](/wiki/Francie_Schwartz "Francie Schwartz"), an
American who was in London to discuss a film proposal with Apple, began living
with McCartney at his [St John's Wood](/wiki/St_John%27s_Wood "St John's
Wood") home.[19][20] When Lennon mentioned that he thought the song was about
him and Ono, McCartney denied it and told Lennon he had written the song about
himself.[21][nb 2]

Author [Mark Hertsgaard](/wiki/Mark_Hertsgaard "Mark Hertsgaard") has
commented that "many of the song's lyrics do seem directed more at a grown man
on the verge of a powerful new love, especially the lines 'you have found her
now go and get her' and 'you're waiting for someone to perform with.'"[21]
Music critic and author [Tim Riley](/wiki/Tim_Riley_\(music_critic\) "Tim
Riley \(music critic\)") writes: "If the song is about self-worth and self-
consolation in the face of hardship, the vocal performance itself conveys much
of the journey. He begins by singing to comfort someone else, finds himself
weighing his own feelings in the process, and finally, in the repeated
refrains that nurture his own approbation, he comes to believe in
himself."[23]

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Production")]

### Abbey Road
rehearsals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Abbey Road rehearsals")]

Having earmarked the song for release as a single, the Beatles recorded "Hey
Jude" during the sessions for their [self-titled double
album](/wiki/The_Beatles_\(album\) "The Beatles \(album\)"), commonly known as
"the White Album".[24][25] The sessions were marked by an element of discord
within the group for the first time, partly as a result of Ono's constant
presence at Lennon's side,[26][27] and also reflective of the four band
members' divergence following their [communal trip to
Rishikesh](/wiki/The_Beatles_in_India "The Beatles in India") in the spring of
1968 to study [Transcendental Meditation](/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation
"Transcendental Meditation").[28] Author [Peter Doggett](/wiki/Peter_Doggett
"Peter Doggett") describes the completed version of "Hey Jude" as a song that
"glowed with optimism after a summer that had burned with anxiety and rage
within the group".[29]

The Beatles first taped 25 [takes](/wiki/Take "Take") of the song at
[EMI](/wiki/EMI "EMI")'s [Abbey Road Studios](/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios "Abbey
Road Studios") in London over two nights, 29 and 30 July 1968,[24] with
[George Martin](/wiki/George_Martin "George Martin") as their producer.[30]
These dates served as rehearsals, however, since they planned to record the
master track at [Trident Studios](/wiki/Trident_Studios "Trident Studios") to
utilise their [eight-track recording machine](/wiki/Multitrack_recording
"Multitrack recording") (Abbey Road was still limited to four-tracks).[24] A
take from 29 July, which author and critic [Kenneth
Womack](/wiki/Kenneth_Womack "Kenneth Womack") describes as a "jovial"
session,[31] was issued on the _[Anthology 3](/wiki/Anthology_3 "Anthology
3")_ compilation in 1996.[32]

The 30 July rehearsals were filmed for a short documentary titled _Music!_[33]
However, the film shows only three of the Beatles performing "Hey Jude", as
[George Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison "George Harrison") remained in the
studio control room,[34] with Martin and EMI recording engineer [Ken
Scott](/wiki/Ken_Scott "Ken Scott").[35][nb 3] Author Simon Leng views this as
indicative of how Harrison was increasingly allowed little room to develop
ideas on McCartney compositions, whereas he was free to create empathetic
guitar parts for Lennon's songs of the period.[37]

During the rehearsals that day,[35] Harrison and McCartney had a heated
disagreement over the lead guitar part for the song.[31] Harrison's idea was
to play a guitar phrase as a response to each line of the vocal,[38] which did
not fit with McCartney's conception of the song's arrangement, and he vetoed
it.[39][40] In a 1994 interview, McCartney said, "looking back on it, I think,
Okay. Well, it was bossy, but it was ballsy of me, because I could have bowed
to the pressure."[40] [Ron Richards](/wiki/Ron_Richards_\(producer\) "Ron
Richards \(producer\)"), a record producer who worked for Martin at both
[Parlophone](/wiki/Parlophone "Parlophone") and [AIR
Studios](/wiki/Associated_Independent_Recording "Associated Independent
Recording"),[41] said McCartney was "oblivious to anyone else's feelings in
the studio", and that he was driven to making the best possible record, at
almost any cost.[42][nb 4]

### Trident Studios
recording[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Trident Studios recording")]

The master track for "Hey Jude" was recorded at Trident Studios on 31
July.[33] Trident's founder, [Norman Sheffield](/wiki/Norman_Sheffield "Norman
Sheffield"), recalled that [Mal Evans](/wiki/Mal_Evans "Mal Evans"), the
Beatles' aide and former roadie, insisted that some pot plants he had brought
be placed in the studio to make the place "soft", consistent with the band's
wishes.[46] Sheffield served as [recording engineer](/wiki/Recording_engineer
"Recording engineer") for the session. The line-up on the basic track was
McCartney on piano and lead vocal, Lennon on acoustic guitar, Harrison on
electric guitar, and [Ringo Starr](/wiki/Ringo_Starr "Ringo Starr") on
drums.[39]

The Beatles recorded four takes of "Hey Jude", the first of which was selected
as the master.[39] With drums absent for the first 50 seconds of the song,
McCartney began this take unaware that Starr had just left for a toilet break.
Starr soon returned – "tiptoeing past my back rather quickly", in McCartney's
recollection – and performed his cue perfectly. McCartney added: "his timing
was absolutely impeccable."[40]

On 1 August, the group carried out [overdubs](/wiki/Overdubbing "Overdubbing")
on the basic track, again at Trident. These additions included McCartney's
lead vocal and bass guitar; backing vocals from Lennon, McCartney and
Harrison; and tambourine,[34] played by Starr.[47] They then added a 36-piece
orchestra over the long [coda](/wiki/Coda_\(music\) "Coda \(music\)"), scored
by Martin.[39] The orchestra consisted of ten violins, three violas, three
cellos, two flutes, one contra bassoon, one bassoon, two clarinets, one contra
bass clarinet, four trumpets, four trombones, two horns, percussion and two
string basses.[47] With the introduction of what musicologist [Walter
Everett](/wiki/Walter_Everett_\(musicologist\) "Walter Everett
\(musicologist\)") terms the "bottom-heavy" orchestral instruments,
particularly the string basses, McCartney's bass part was cut from the start
of the coda onwards.[48]

According to Sheffield, there was dissension initially among the orchestral
musicians, some of whom "were looking down their noses at the Beatles, I
think". Sheffield recalls that McCartney ensured their cooperation by
demanding: "Do you guys want to get fucking paid or not?" During the first few
takes, McCartney was unhappy about the lack of energy and passion in the
orchestra's performance, so he stood up on the grand piano and started
conducting the musicians from there.[49]

The Beatles then asked the orchestra members if they would clap their hands
and sing along to the refrain in the coda. All but one of the musicians
complied (for a double fee), with the abstainer reportedly saying, "I'm not
going to clap my hands and sing Paul McCartney's bloody song!"[39] Apple
Records assistant Chris O'Dell says she joined the cast of backing singers on
the song;[50] one of the label's first signings, [Jackie
Lomax](/wiki/Jackie_Lomax "Jackie Lomax"), also recalled participating.[51]

Trident was paid £25 per hour by EMI for the "Hey Jude" sessions. Sheffield
said that the studio earned about £1000 in total at the time, but by having
the Beatles record there, and in turn raving about the facility, the value was
incalculable.[52] The band carried out further work at Trident during
1968,[53] and Apple artists such as Lomax, [Mary Hopkin](/wiki/Mary_Hopkin
"Mary Hopkin"), [Billy Preston](/wiki/Billy_Preston "Billy Preston") and the
Iveys all recorded there over the next year.[54][nb 5]

### Mixing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Mixing")]

Scott, Martin and the Beatles mixed the finished recording at Abbey Road.[10]
The transfer of the Trident master tape to [acetate](/wiki/Acetate_disc
"Acetate disc") proved problematic due to the recording sounding murky when
played back on EMI's equipment.[10] The issue was resolved with the help of
[Geoff Emerick](/wiki/Geoff_Emerick "Geoff Emerick"),[55][56] whom Scott had
recently replaced as the Beatles' principal recording engineer.[57] Emerick
happened to be visiting Abbey Road,[58] having recently refused to work with
the Beatles any longer, due to the tension and abuse that had become
commonplace at their recording sessions.[59][60] A stereo mix of "Hey Jude"
was then completed on 2 August and the mono version on 8 August.[61][nb 6]

Everett writes that the song's "most commented-on feature" is its considerable
length, at 7:11.[63] The precedent for issuing such a long track on a single
had recently been set by [Richard Harris](/wiki/Richard_Harris "Richard
Harris")' hit recording of "[MacArthur Park](/wiki/MacArthur_Park_\(song\)
"MacArthur Park \(song\)")",[64] the composer of which, [Jimmy
Webb](/wiki/Jimmy_Webb "Jimmy Webb"), was a visitor to the studio around this
time.[65] According to Webb, Martin admitted to him that "Hey Jude" was only
allowed to run over seven minutes because of the success of "MacArthur
Park".[66]

In the song's final bridge section, at 2:58,[67] the spoken phrase "Fucking
hell!" appears. Scott admits that although he was told about it, he could not
hear the words originally.[10] Lennon attributed the expletive to McCartney,
according to Emerick,[56] who reports Lennon's comment in his autobiography:
"'Paul hit a clunker on the piano and said a naughty word,' Lennon gleefully
crowed, 'but I insisted we leave it in [at Trident], buried just low enough so
that it can barely be heard. Most people won't ever spot it ... but we'll know
it's there.'"[68] Womack considers that the expletive was actually uttered by
Lennon.[67] [Malcolm Toft](/wiki/Malcolm_Toft "Malcolm Toft"), the mix
engineer on the Trident recording,[69] also attributes it to Lennon.[70] In
Toft's recollection, Lennon was overdubbing his harmony vocal when, in
reaction to the volume being too loud in his headphones, he first called out
"Whoa!" then, two seconds later, swore as he pulled the headphones off.[71][nb
7]

## Composition and
structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Composition and structure")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/HeyJude68sheet.jpg/145px-
HeyJude68sheet.jpg)](/wiki/File:HeyJude68sheet.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:HeyJude68sheet.jpg "Enlarge")

1968 sheet music cover (Maclen Music, Inc., New York)

"Hey Jude" begins with McCartney singing lead vocals and playing the piano.
The patterns he plays are based on three chords: F, C, and B♭ (I, V and
IV).[1] The main chord progression is "flipped on its head", in Hertsgaard's
words, for the coda, since the C chord is replaced by E♭.[72] Everett comments
that McCartney's melody over the verses borrows in part from [John
Ireland](/wiki/John_Ireland_\(composer\) "John Ireland \(composer\)")'s 1907
[liturgical](/wiki/Liturgical_music "Liturgical music") piece _Te Deum_ , as
well as (with the first change to a B♭ chord) suggesting the influence of [the
Drifters](/wiki/The_Drifters "The Drifters")' 1960 hit "[Save the Last Dance
for Me](/wiki/Save_the_Last_Dance_for_Me "Save the Last Dance for Me")".[63]

The second verse of the song adds accompaniment from acoustic guitar and
tambourine. Tim Riley writes that, with the "restrained tom-tom and cymbal
fill" that introduces the drum part, "the piano shifts downward to add a flat
seventh to the tonic chord, making the downbeat of the bridge the point of
arrival ('And any time you feel the _pain_ ')."[73] At the end of each bridge,
McCartney sings a brief phrase ("Na-na-na na …"), supported by an electric
guitar fill,[34] before playing a piano fill that leads to the next verse.
According to Riley, this vocal phrase serves to "reorient the harmony for the
verse as the piano figure turns upside down into a vocal aside". Additional
musical details, such as tambourine on the third verse and subtle harmonies
accompanying the lead vocal, are added to sustain interest throughout the
four-verse, two-bridge song.[74]

The verse-bridge structure persists for approximately three minutes, after
which the band leads into a four-minute-long coda, consisting of nineteen
rounds of the song's double [plagal cadence](/wiki/Plagal_cadence "Plagal
cadence").[63] During this coda, the rest of the band, backed by an orchestra
that also provides backing vocals, repeats the phrase "Na-na-na na" followed
by the words "hey Jude" until the song gradually fades out. In his analysis of
the composition, musicologist [Alan Pollack](/wiki/Alan_W._Pollack "Alan W.
Pollack") comments on the unusual structure of "Hey Jude", in that it uses a
"binary form that combines a fully developed, hymn-like song together with an
extended, [mantra](/wiki/Mantra "Mantra")-like jam on a simple chord
progression".[75]

Riley considers that the coda's repeated chord sequence (I-♭VII-IV-I) "answers
all the musical questions raised at the beginnings and ends of bridges", since
"The flat seventh that posed dominant turns into bridges now has an entire
chord built on it." This three-chord refrain allows McCartney "a bedding ...
to leap about on vocally",[76] so he ad-libs his vocal performance for the
rest of the song. In Riley's estimation, the song "becomes a tour of Paul's
vocal range: from the graceful inviting tones of the opening verse, through
the mounting excitement of the song itself, to the surging raves of the
coda".[23]

## Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Release")]

[The Beatles] are confident and cheerful and the human condition will be
thrilled by the coming results of their willing and enduring Beatle bondage …
they will give all of us new wonders to soothe our pain.[77]

– [Derek Taylor](/wiki/Derek_Taylor "Derek Taylor"), "Hey Jude" press release,
August 1968

"Hey Jude" was released on 26 August 1968 in the United States and 30 August
in the United Kingdom,[78] backed with
"[Revolution](/wiki/Revolution_\(Beatles_song\) "Revolution \(Beatles
song\)")" on the [B-side](/wiki/A-side_and_B-side "A-side and B-side") of a 7"
single.[79] It was one of four singles issued simultaneously to launch Apple
Records – the others being Mary Hopkin's "[Those Were the
Days](/wiki/Those_Were_the_Days_\(song\) "Those Were the Days \(song\)")",
Jackie Lomax's "[Sour Milk Sea](/wiki/Sour_Milk_Sea "Sour Milk Sea")", and the
Black Dyke Mills Band's "Thingumybob".[80] In advance of the release date,
Apple declared 11–18 August to be "National Apple Week" in the UK,[80][81] and
sent gift-wrapped boxes of the records, marked "Our First Four", to [Queen
Elizabeth II](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II "Queen Elizabeth II") and other members
of the [royal family](/wiki/British_Royal_Family "British Royal Family"), and
to [Harold Wilson](/wiki/Harold_Wilson "Harold Wilson"), the prime minister at
the time.[82] The release was promoted by [Derek Taylor](/wiki/Derek_Taylor
"Derek Taylor"), who, in Doggett's description, "hyped the first Apple records
with typical elan".[83] "Hey Jude" was the first of the four singles, since it
was still designated as an EMI/Parlophone release in the UK and a
[Capitol](/wiki/Capitol_Records "Capitol Records") release in the US, but with
the Apple Records logo now added.[84][nb 8] In the US, "Hey Jude" was the
first Beatles single to be issued in a company sleeve rather than a picture
sleeve.[86]

Lennon wanted "Revolution" to be the A-side of the single, but the other
Beatles did not agree.[87] In his 1970 interview with _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ , he said "Hey Jude" was worthy
of an A-side, "but we could have had both."[88] In 1980, he told
_[Playboy](/wiki/Playboy "Playboy")_ he still disagreed with the decision.[89]

The single was a highly successful debut for Apple Records,[90] and contrasted
with the public embarrassment the band faced after the recent closure of their
short-lived retail venture, [Apple Boutique](/wiki/Apple_Boutique "Apple
Boutique").[55] "Hey Jude" began its sixteen-week run on Britain's [official
singles chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart") on 7 September 1968,
claiming the top spot a week later. It lasted two weeks on top before being
replaced by Hopkin's "Those Were the Days", which was produced by
McCartney.[91] "Hey Jude" was certified [gold](/wiki/RIAA_certification "RIAA
certification") by the [Recording Industry Association of
America](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry
Association of America") (RIAA) on 13 September; that same week,
_[NME](/wiki/NME "NME")_ reported that two million copies of the single had
been sold.[92] The song entered the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") in the US on 14 September,
beginning a nineteen-week chart run there.[93] It reached number one on 28
September and held that position for nine weeks,[94] for three of which,
"Those Were the Days" held the number-two spot.[93] This was the longest time
spent by a Beatles single at number one,[95] as well as being the longest-
playing single to reach number one.[94] The song was the 16th number-one hit
for the band in America, tying [Elvis Presley](/wiki/Elvis_Presley "Elvis
Presley")'s record at the time for most number-one songs there. _Billboard_
ranked it as the [number-one song for 1968](/wiki/Billboard_Year-
End_Hot_100_singles_of_1968 "Billboard Year-End Hot 100 singles of 1968").[94]

In the UK, where "MacArthur Park" had failed to top the chart, "Hey Jude"
remained the longest number-one hit for nearly a quarter of a century. It was
surpassed in 1993 by [Meat Loaf](/wiki/Meat_Loaf "Meat Loaf")'s "[I'd Do
Anything for Love (But I Won't Do
That)](/wiki/I%27d_Do_Anything_for_Love_\(But_I_Won%27t_Do_That\) "I'd Do
Anything for Love \(But I Won't Do That\)")", which ran to 7:52 as a
single.[96]

On 30 November 1968, _NME_ reported that sales had reached nearly six million
copies worldwide.[97][98] "Hey Jude" became the biggest-selling debut release
for a record label ever, selling an estimated eight million copies worldwide
and topping the charts in eleven countries.[91] In 1999, it was certified [4x
platinum](/wiki/RIAA_certification "RIAA certification") by the RIAA,
representing four million units shipped in the US.[99]

## Promotion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Promotion")]

A failed early promotional attempt for the single took place after the
Beatles' all-night recording session on 7–8 August 1968.[100] With Apple
Boutique having closed a week before, McCartney and his girlfriend, Francie
Schwartz, painted _Hey Jude/Revolution_ across its large,
[whitewashed](/wiki/Whitewash "Whitewash") shop windows.[101] The words were
mistaken for [anti-Semitic](/wiki/Anti-Semitism "Anti-Semitism") graffiti
(since _Jude_ means "Jew" in German),[101] leading to complaints from the
local Jewish community,[80][102] and the windows being smashed by passers-
by.[103] Discussing the episode in _[The Beatles
Anthology](/wiki/The_Beatles_Anthology_\(book\) "The Beatles Anthology
\(book\)")_ , McCartney explained that he had been motivated by the location –
"Great opportunity. [Baker Street](/wiki/Baker_Street "Baker Street"),
millions of buses going around …" – and added: "I had no idea it meant 'Jew',
but if you look at footage of [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi
Germany"), '_Juden Raus_ ' was written in whitewashed windows with a [Star of
David](/wiki/Star_of_David "Star of David"). I swear it never occurred to
me."[13] According to [Barry Miles](/wiki/Barry_Miles "Barry Miles"),
McCartney caused further controversy in his comments to Alan Smith of the
_NME_ that month when he said: "Starvation in India doesn't worry me one bit,
not one iota … And it doesn't worry you, if you're honest. You just
pose."[80][nb 9]

The Beatles hired [Michael Lindsay-Hogg](/wiki/Michael_Lindsay-Hogg "Michael
Lindsay-Hogg") to shoot a promotional clip for "Hey Jude", after he had
previously directed a clip for "[Paperback Writer](/wiki/Paperback_Writer
"Paperback Writer")" in 1966. They settled on the idea of shooting with a
live, albeit controlled, audience. In the clip, the Beatles are first seen by
themselves, performing the initial chorus and verses, and then are joined by
the audience who appear as the last chorus concludes and coda begins; the
audience sings and claps along with the Beatles through the song's conclusion.
Hogg shot the clip at [Twickenham Film Studios](/wiki/Twickenham_Film_Studios
"Twickenham Film Studios") on 4 September 1968, with McCartney himself
designing the set. Tony Bramwell, a friend of the Beatles, later described the
set as "the piano, there; drums, there; and orchestra in two tiers at the
back."[104] The event marked Starr's return to the group, after McCartney's
criticism of his drumming had led to him walking out during a session for the
White Album track "[Back in the U.S.S.R.](/wiki/Back_in_the_U.S.S.R. "Back in
the U.S.S.R.")"[105][106] During his two-week absence, Starr announced that he
had left the band.[104]

The final edit was a combination of several different takes[107] and included
"introductions" to the song by [David Frost](/wiki/David_Frost "David Frost")
(who introduced the Beatles as "the greatest tea-room orchestra in the
world"),[108] and [Cliff Richard](/wiki/Cliff_Richard "Cliff Richard"), for
their respective, eponymous TV programmes.[107] As shooting wore on, Lennon
repeatedly asked Lindsay-Hogg if he had the material he needed. After 12
takes, McCartney said, "I think that's enough", and shooting concluded.[107]
It was first aired in the UK on _Frost on Sunday_ on 8 September 1968,[109]
and the clip was later broadcast for the United States on _[The Smothers
Brothers Comedy Hour](/wiki/The_Smothers_Brothers_Comedy_Hour "The Smothers
Brothers Comedy Hour")_ on 6 October.[110] According to Riley, the showing on
_Frost on Sunday_ "kicked 'Hey Jude' into the stratosphere" in terms of
popularity.[111] Hertsgaard pairs it with the release of the animated film
_[Yellow Submarine](/wiki/Yellow_Submarine_\(film\) "Yellow Submarine
\(film\)")_ as two events that created "a state of nirvana" for Beatles fans,
in contrast with the problems besetting the band regarding Ono's influence and
Apple.[112]

The 4 September 1968 promo clip is included in the Beatles' 2015 video
compilation _[1](/wiki/1_\(Beatles_album\) "1 \(Beatles album\)")_ , while the
three-disc versions of that compilation, titled _1+_ , also include an
alternate video, with a different introduction and vocal, from the same
date.[113]

## Critical reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

Upon the single's release, Derek Johnson of the _NME_ wrote: "The intriguing
features of 'Hey Jude' are its extreme length and the 40-piece orchestral
accompaniment – and personally I would have preferred it without either!"
While he viewed the track overall as "a beautiful, compelling song", and the
first three minutes as "absolutely sensational", Johnson rued the long coda's
"vocal improvisations on the basically repetitive four-bar chorus".[114]
_[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_ magazine described the
coda as "a fadeout that engagingly spoofs the fadeout as a gimmick for ending
pop records". The same reviewer contrasted "Hey Jude" with its B-side,
"Revolution", saying that "The other side of the new disk urges activism of a
different sort", due to McCartney "liltingly exhort[ing] a friend to overcome
his fears and commit himself in love".[115] _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ also attributed the song's
meaning as a message from McCartney to Lennon to end his negative
relationships with women: "to break the old pattern; to really go through with
love".[116] Other commentators interpreted "Hey Jude" as being directed at
[Bob Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan"), then semi-retired in
[Woodstock](/wiki/Woodstock,_New_York "Woodstock, New York").[117][118]

Writing in 1971, [Robert Christgau](/wiki/Robert_Christgau "Robert Christgau")
of _[The Village Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_ called
it "one of [McCartney's] truest and most forthright love songs" and was
critical of its omission from the album _[The
Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles_\(album\) "The Beatles \(album\)")_.[119] In their
1975 book _[The Beatles: An Illustrated
Record](/wiki/The_Beatles:_An_Illustrated_Record "The Beatles: An Illustrated
Record")_ , critics [Roy Carr](/wiki/Roy_Carr "Roy Carr") and [Tony
Tyler](/wiki/Tony_Tyler "Tony Tyler") wrote that "Hey Jude" "promised great
things" for the ill-conceived Apple enterprise and described the song as "the
last great Beatles single recorded _specifically_ for the 45s market". They
noted also that "the epic proportions of the piece" encouraged many imitators,
yet these other artists "[failed] to capture the gentleness and sympathy of
the Beatles' communal feel".[118]

Among more recent commentators, Alan Pollack admires "Hey Jude" as "such a
good illustration of two compositional lessons – how to fill a large canvas
with simple means, and how to use diverse elements such as harmony, bassline,
and orchestration to articulate form and contrast."[75] Pollack considers that
the song's long coda provides "an astonishingly transcendental effect",[75]
while [AllMusic](/wiki/AllMusic "AllMusic")'s [Richie
Unterberger](/wiki/Richie_Unterberger "Richie Unterberger") similarly opines:
"What could have very easily been boring is instead hypnotic because McCartney
varies the vocal with some of the greatest nonsense scatting ever heard in
rock …"[16] In his book _[Revolution in the Head](/wiki/Revolution_in_the_Head
"Revolution in the Head")_ , [Ian MacDonald](/wiki/Ian_MacDonald "Ian
MacDonald") wrote that the "pseudo-soul shrieking in the fade-out may be a
blemish" but he praised the song as "a pop/rock hybrid drawing on the best of
both idioms".[120] MacDonald concluded: "'Hey Jude' strikes a universal note,
touching on an archetypal moment in male sexual psychology with a gentle
wisdom one might properly call inspired."[117] Lennon said the song was "one
of [McCartney's] masterpieces".[14]

## Awards and
accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Awards and accolades")]

"Hey Jude" was nominated for the [Grammy Awards of
1969](/wiki/11th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "11th Annual Grammy Awards") in the
categories of [Record of the Year](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Record_of_the_Year
"Grammy Award for Record of the Year"), [Song of the
Year](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Song_of_the_Year "Grammy Award for Song of the
Year") and [Best Pop Performance by a Duo or Group with
Vocal](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Pop_Performance_by_a_Duo_or_Group_with_Vocals
"Grammy Award for Best Pop Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals"), but
failed to win any of them.[121] In the 1968 _NME_ Readers' Poll, "Hey Jude"
was named the best single of the year,[122] and the song also won the 1968
[Ivor Novello Award](/wiki/Ivor_Novello_Awards "Ivor Novello Awards") for
"A-Side With the Highest Sales".[123] In 2001, "Hey Jude" was inducted into
the [National Academy of Recording Arts and
Sciences](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Recording_Arts_and_Sciences "National
Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences") Grammy Hall of Fame.[124]

In 2004, _Rolling Stone_ ranked "Hey Jude" at number eight on the "[500
Greatest Songs of All
Time](/wiki/Rolling_Stone%27s_500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "Rolling Stone's
500 Greatest Songs of All Time")", making it the highest-placed Beatles song
on the list.[125] Among its many appearances in other best-song-of-all-time
lists, [VH1](/wiki/VH1 "VH1") placed it seventh in 2000 and
_[Mojo](/wiki/Mojo_\(magazine\) "Mojo \(magazine\)")_ ranked it at number 29
in the same year, having placed the song seventh in a 1997 list of "The 100
Greatest Singles of All Time".[126] In 1976, the _NME_ ranked it 38th on the
magazine's "Top 100 Singles of All Time", and the track appeared at number 77
on the same publication's "The 500 Greatest Songs of All Time" in 2014.[126]
In January 2001, "Hey Jude" came in third on [Channel 4](/wiki/Channel_4
"Channel 4")'s list of the "100 Greatest Singles".[127] The Amusement & Music
Operators Association ranks "Hey Jude" as the 11th-best
[jukebox](/wiki/Jukebox "Jukebox") single of all time.[128] In 2008, the song
appeared in eighth place on _Billboard_ 's "All Time Hot 100 Songs".[67]

In July 2006, _Mojo_ placed "Hey Jude" at number 12 on its list of "The 101
Greatest Beatles Songs" (between "[Eleanor Rigby](/wiki/Eleanor_Rigby "Eleanor
Rigby")" and "[Come Together](/wiki/Come_Together "Come Together")").[129] On
a similar list compiled four years later, _Rolling Stone_ ranked the song at
number seven.[130] In 2015, the [ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV
network\)") program _The Nation 's Favourite Beatles Number One_ ranked "Hey
Jude" in first place.[131]

## Auctioned lyrics and
memorabilia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Auctioned lyrics and memorabilia")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Julian_Lennon.jpg/140px-
Julian_Lennon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Julian_Lennon.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Julian_Lennon.jpg "Enlarge")

Julian Lennon (pictured at the [John Lennon Peace
Monument](/wiki/John_Lennon_Peace_Monument "John Lennon Peace Monument") in
2010) bid successfully for the Beatles' recording notes for the song at an
auction in 1996.

Julian Lennon discovered that "Hey Jude" had been written for him almost 20
years after McCartney composed the song. He recalled of his and McCartney's
relationship: "Paul and I used to hang about quite a bit – more than Dad and I
did. We had a great friendship going and there seems to be far more pictures
of me and Paul playing together at that age than there are pictures of me and
my dad."[12] In 1996, Julian paid £25,000 for the recording notes to "Hey
Jude" at an auction. He spent a further £35,000 at the auction, buying John
Lennon memorabilia. John Cousins, Julian Lennon's manager, stated at the time:
"He has a few photographs of his father, but not very much else. He is
collecting for personal reasons; these are family heirlooms if you like."[132]

In 2002, the original handwritten lyrics for the song were nearly auctioned
off at [Christie's](/wiki/Christie%27s "Christie's") in London. The sheet of
notepaper with the scrawled lyrics had been expected to fetch up to £80,000 at
the auction, which was scheduled for 30 April 2002. McCartney went to court to
stop the auction, claiming the paper had disappeared from his West London
home. Richard Morgan, representing Christie's, said McCartney had provided no
evidence that he had ever owned the piece of paper on which the lyrics were
written. The courts decided in McCartney's favour and prohibited the sale of
the lyrics. They had been sent to Christie's for auction by Frenchman Florrent
Tessier, who said he purchased the piece of paper at a street market stall in
London for £10 in the early 1970s. In the original catalogue for the auction,
Julian Lennon had written, "It's very strange to think that someone has
written a song about you. It still touches me."[133]

## Cover versions and
performances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Cover versions and performances")]

"Hey Jude" was one of the few Beatles songs that [Elvis
Presley](/wiki/Elvis_Presley "Elvis Presley") covered, when he rehearsed the
track at his 1969 [Memphis sessions](/wiki/From_Elvis_in_Memphis#Recording
"From Elvis in Memphis") with producer [Chips Moman](/wiki/Chips_Moman "Chips
Moman"), a recording that appeared on the 1972 album _[Elvis
Now](/wiki/Elvis_Now "Elvis Now")_.[134] A [medley](/wiki/Medley_\(music\)
"Medley \(music\)") of the Beatles'
"[Yesterday](/wiki/Yesterday_\(Beatles_song\) "Yesterday \(Beatles song\)")"
and "Hey Jude" was included on the 1999 reissue of Presley's 1970 live album
_[On Stage](/wiki/On_Stage_\(Elvis_Presley_album\) "On Stage \(Elvis Presley
album\)")_.[135]

In 1968, R&B singer [Wilson Pickett](/wiki/Wilson_Pickett "Wilson Pickett")
released a cover recorded at [Muscle Shoals](/wiki/Muscle_Shoals_Sound_Studio
"Muscle Shoals Sound Studio"),[136] with guitar from a young [Duane
Allman](/wiki/Duane_Allman "Duane Allman"), who recommended the choice to
Pickett.[137] [Eric Clapton](/wiki/Eric_Clapton "Eric Clapton") commented, "I
remember hearing [it] and calling either [Ahmet Ertegun](/wiki/Ahmet_Ertegun
"Ahmet Ertegun") or [Tom Dowd](/wiki/Tom_Dowd "Tom Dowd") and saying, 'Who's
that guitar player?'...To this day, I've never heard better rock guitar
playing on an R&B record. It's the best."[138] Pickett commented on the outro
that "people were going crazy" and session musician [Jimmy
Johnson](/wiki/Jimmy_Johnson_\(musician\) "Jimmy Johnson \(musician\)") said
that the Allman's solo "created [Southern rock](/wiki/Southern_rock "Southern
rock")".[136]

["Weird Al" Yankovic](/wiki/%22Weird_Al%22_Yankovic ""Weird Al" Yankovic")
included "Hey Jude" in his first polka medley, "[Polkas on
45](/wiki/Polkas_on_45 "Polkas on 45")", from his 1984 album _["Weird Al"
Yankovic in 3-D](/wiki/%22Weird_Al%22_Yankovic_in_3-D ""Weird Al" Yankovic in
3-D")_.[139] [Katy Perry](/wiki/Katy_Perry "Katy Perry") performed a cover of
the song as part of the 2012 [MusiCares](/wiki/MusiCares "MusiCares") Person
of the Year concert honouring McCartney.[140]

Paul McCartney sang the song in the closing moments of the [opening
ceremony](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony "2012 Summer Olympics
opening ceremony") of the [2012 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics
"2012 Summer Olympics") hosted in [London](/wiki/London "London"). On 4 August
2012, McCartney led the crowd in a rendition of "Hey Jude" while watching
cycling at the velodrome.[141]

## Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hey_Jude&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** Griffith added that he and his fellow Iveys were "gobsmacked" by the performance.[12]
  2. **Jump up ^** In a 1971 interview with Jonathan Cott, Lennon recalled his and McCartney's conversation: "Ah, it's me! I said, it's _me_! He says, no it's _me_. I said, check, we're going through the same bit."[22]
  3. **Jump up ^** Produced by the National Music Council of Great Britain,[36] the documentary was released in October 1969.[34]
  4. **Jump up ^** Described by [Ian MacDonald](/wiki/Ian_MacDonald "Ian MacDonald") as "a tense moment",[43] this disagreement between Harrison and McCartney was recalled by the pair in a similar argument they had while filming _[Let It Be](/wiki/Let_It_Be_\(1970_film\) "Let It Be \(1970 film\)")_ in January 1969,[34] regarding the lead guitar part on "[Two of Us](/wiki/Two_of_Us_\(song\) "Two of Us \(song\)")".[44] Partly as a result of McCartney's criticism, Harrison briefly quit the band on 10 January.[34][45]
  5. **Jump up ^** In 2013 McCartney agreed to write the foreword to Sheffield's book "Life on Two Legs", partly because of his positive experience when recording "Hey Jude".
  6. **Jump up ^** Writing in his 2006 memoir, Emerick says that "Obviously something at Trident had been misaligned", and the solution for "Hey Jude" was to add "massive amounts of treble [equalization](/wiki/Equalization_\(audio\) "Equalization \(audio\)")".[62]
  7. **Jump up ^** Toft adds: "because it had been bounced down [mixed] with the main vocal, it could not be removed. I just managed to bring the fader down for a split second on the mix to try to lessen the effect."[71]
  8. **Jump up ^** The catalogue numbers for "Hey Jude"/"Revolution" – Apple 5722 in the UK and 2276 in the US – were consistent with the numerical sequencing of the Beatles' previous releases on Parlophone and Capitol. Apple's other three debut singles followed a new sequencing, starting with "Those Were the Days", which was issued as Apple 2 and Apple 1801.[85]
  9. **Jump up ^** Having told Smith, "The truth about me is that I'm pleasantly insincere", McCartney said: "You can't pretend to me that an [Oxfam](/wiki/Oxfam "Oxfam") ad can reach down into the depths of your soul and actually make you feel for those [starving] people – more, for instance, than you feel about getting a new car."[80]
  10. **Jump up ^** EMI archives do not record the names of the studio musicians, but it has been established that two of the cellists were [Alexander "Bobby" Kok](/wiki/Alexander_Kok "Alexander Kok") and Peter Halling, and two of the flautists were Bill Jackman and Brian Warren.
